questions.text: A 39 year old male with aortic insufficiency and a history of no drug allergies is given an intravenous dose of antibiotic as a prophylaxis preceding the insertion of a valve prosthesis. As the antibiotic is being infused, the patient becomes flushed over most of his body. What antibiotic was given?
questions.solution:
• The "red man" syndrome istypically associated with vancomycin, thought to be caused by histamine release.
  • Prevention consists of a slower infusion rate and pretreatment with antihistamines.
  • Systemic toxicity of vancomycin is relatively high.
  • It can cause concentration-dependent nerve deafness which may be permanent.
  • Kidney damage is also dose-related. Other oto and nephrotoxic drugs like aminoglycosides must be very carefully administered when vancomycin is being used.
  • Skin allergy and fall in BP during i.v. injection can occur. Vancomycin has the potential to release histamine by direct action on mast cells.
  • Rapid i.v. injection has caused chills, fever, urticaria and intense flushing- called "Red man syndrome".

Key Takeaway

  • Rapid i.v. injection has caused chills, fever, urticaria and intense flushing- called "Red man syndrome".
  • Skin allergy and fall in BP during i.v. injection can occur. Vancomycin has the potential to release histamine by direct action on mast cells.

[Good to Know]

[Vancomycin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number: 806

questions.text: Which of the following is a least common indication of cotrimoxazole?
questions.solution:
• Oral Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (Tmp-Smz)
    • A combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is effective treatment for a wide variety of infections including P jiroveci pneumonia, shigellosis, systemic salmonella infections, urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and some non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections.
  • Uses:
    1. Urinary tract infections
      • Most acute uncomplicated infections respond rapidly.
      • Cotrimoxazole is specially valuable for chronic or recurrent cases or in prostatitis, because trimethoprim is concentrated in prostate due to relatively acidic pH of prostatic fluid.
    2. Respiratory tract infections
      • Both upper and lower respiratory tract infections, including chronic bronchitis and facio-maxillary infections, otitis media caused by gram positive cocci and influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis respond well.
    3. Bacterial diarrhoeas and dysentery
      • Cotrimoxazole may be used for severe and invasive infections by coli, Shigella, nontyphoid Salmonella, and Y. enterocolitica
    4. Pneumocystis jiroveci
      • It causes severe pneumonia in neutropenic and AIDS patients.
      • Cotrimoxazole has prophylactic as well as therapeutic value, but high doses are needed.
    5. Chancroid
      • Cotrimoxazole is a rarely used alternative to ceftriaxone/azithromycin.
    6. Typhoid
      • Initially cotrimoxazole was an effective alternative to chloramphenicol.
  • Key Takeaway
    • A combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is effective treatment for a wide variety of infections including P jiroveci pneumonia, shigellosis, systemic salmonella infections, urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and some non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections.

[Good to Know]

[Cotrimoxazole]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 756

questions.text: The elimination half-life of which of the following tetracyclines remains unchanged when the drug is administered to an anuric patient?
questions.solution:
• All tetracyclines can produce negative nitrogen balance and increased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels. This is of clinical importance in patients with impaired renal function.
  • With the exception of doxycycline, tetracyclines should not be used in patients that are anuric.
  • Doxycycline is excreted by the GI tract under these conditions, and it will not accumulate in the serum of patients with renal insufficiency.
  • Most tetracyclines are primarily excreted in urine by glomerular filtration; dose has to be reduced in renal failure; doxycycline is an exception to this.
  • Key Takeaway
    • All tetracyclines can produce negative nitrogen balance and increased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels. This is of clinical importance in patients with impaired renal function.
    • With the exception of doxycycline, tetracyclines should not be used in patients that are anuric.

[Good to Know]

[Doxycycline]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 786

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with right lower quadrant pain with guarding and rebound rigidity. A computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrates appendicitis and he is taken to the operating room. What would be a good antibiotic to administer prophylactically before the surgery?
questions.solution:
• Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin, is often used for surgical prophylaxis because it has activity against most gram-positive and some gram-negative organisms.
  • Cefazolin
    • It is the prototype first generation cephalosporin that is active against most PnG sensitive organisms, i.e. Streptococci (pyogenes as well as viridans), gonococci, meningococci, diphtheriae, H. influenzae, clostridia and Actinomyces.
    • Cefazolin attains higher concentration in plasma and in bile.
    • It is the preferred parenteral first generation cephalosporin, especially for surgical prophylaxis.
    • Cefazolin (i.m. or i.v.) is employed for most types of surgeries including those with surgical prosthesis such as artificial heart valves, artificial joints, etc.
    • Cefazolin is the drug of choice for surgical prophylaxis.

Option B & C: Second-generation agents (cefoxitin) and third-generation agents (ceftriaxone) are not used because they have less gram-positive coverage.

Option D: Aztreonam lacks activity against anaerobes and gram-positive organisms. Oxacillin is primarily active against staphylococci.

  • Key Takeaway
    • Surgical prophylaxis: the first generation cephalosporins are popular drugs.
    • Cefazolin (i.m. or i.v.) is employed for most types of surgeries including those with surgical prosthesis such as artificial heart valves, artificial joints, etc.

[Must Know]

[Cefazolin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 776-781

questions.text: A 23 year old woman, who is 23 weeks pregnant, develops a bladder infection due to Pseudomonas spp. She has a documented allergy to penicillin. What is the best choice of treatment given the patient's history and condition?
questions.solution:
• Aztreonam is active against Pseudomonas , appears to be safe during pregnancy, and does not show cross-hypersensitivity with penicillins.
  • Piperacillin is a penicillin group of drug. Cefoxitin is a second generation cephalosporin group of drug. Imipenem is a carbapenem group of drug.
  • Piperacillin, cefoxitin and imipenem all have some overlap in penicillin-allergic patients. Hence Option A, C and D are ruled out.
  • Among the Carbapenem group of drugs Aztreonam is an exception which is effective in patients with penicillin allergy.
  • Aztreonam
    • It is an atypical β-lactam antibiotic in which the other ring is missing (hence monobactam), but acts by binding to specific PBPs.
    • The spectrum of action is narrow, it inhibits gram-negative enteric bacilli and Influenza at very low concentrations and Pseudomonas at moderate concentrations, but does not inhibit gram-positive cocci or faecal anaerobes.
    • The main indications of aztreonam are hospital-acquired infections originating from urinary, biliary, gastrointestinal and female genital tracts.
    • Lack of cross sensitivity with other β-lactam antibiotics except ceftazidime (which has chemical similarity to aztreonam) is the most prominent feature of aztreonam: permiting its use in patients allergic to penicillins or cephalosporins.
    • Rashes and rise in serum aminotransferases are the notable adverse effects.
  • Key Takeaway
    • Aztreonam is active against β-lactamase producing gram negative rods including pseudomonas but has no activity against gram positive organisms or anaerobes.
    • It is the only beta lactam antibiotic that can be used in patients having severe allergy to penicillins or cephalosporins (as it is not cross allergenic).

[Must Know]

[Aztreonam]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:781

questions.text: A 32-year-old man complains of a persistent, dry cough for several days with a mild fever and fatigue. The family physician suspects a diagnosis of pneumonia on clinical grounds, presumably due to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Which of the following groups of antibiotics would be most effective?
questions.solution:
• Macrolides such as azithromycin or clarithromycin are the agents ofchoice for the treatment of mycoplasmal diseases.
  • As a first choice drug for
    1. Atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae
    2. Whooping cough: a 1-2 week course of erythromycin is the most effective treatment for eradicating B. pertussis from upper respiratory tract.
      • Azithromycin, clarithromycin, and chloramphenicol are the alternative antimicrobials.
    3. Chancroid: erythromycin 2 g/day for 7 days is one of the first line drugs, as effective as single dose azithromycin or ceftriaxone

Option A, B & C: As mycoplasmas have no cell wall, drugs such as penicillins, cephalosporins, or vancomycin are ineffective.

Key Takeaway

  • Macrolides such as azithromycin or clarithromycin are the agents ofchoice for the treatment of mycoplasmal diseases.

[Good to Know]

[Macrolides]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number: 801-803

questions.text: An 18-year-old army recruit with a history of G-6-PDH deficiency is to be stationed in African sub-continent. During his tour of duty he develops a cyclic fever, malaise, and weakness. A thin blood smear shows malarial organisms within red blood cells. Which antimalarial is likely to exacerbate the hemolysis, given his enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Primaquine is associated with intravascular hemolysis or methemoglobinuria
  • in G-6-PDH deficiency patients, as it causes oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

Primaquine

  • Unlike other antimalarial drugs, primaquine is a poor erythrocytic schizonti
  • It has weak action on vivax, but blood forms of P. Falciparumare totally insensitive.
  • On the other hand, it is more active against the preerythrocytic stage of falciparum.
  • Primaquine differs from all other available antimalarials in having a marked effect on primary as well as secondary hepatic phases of the malarial parasite.
  • It is highly active against gametocytes and hypnozoites.

Adverse effects

  • The usual doses of primaquine produce only abdominal pain, g.i. upset,weakness or uneasiness in chest as side effect.
  • The most important toxic potential is dose related haemolysis, methaemoglobinaemia, tachypnoea and cyanosis. These effects are due to the oxidant property of primaquine.
  • Those with G-6-PD deficiency are highly susceptible, and haemolytic anaemia can occur with 15-30 mg/day.
  • Primaquine should not be given during pregnancy, because the foetus is G-6-PD deficient

Option A & B: Chloroquine and pyrimethamine do not cause hemolysis, although they are often used with sulfa drugs, which can cause hemolysis in such patients.

Option C: Doxycycline is not known to cause problems in G-6-PDH deficiency.

Key Takeaway

  • Primaquine is associated with intravascular hemolysis or methemoglobinuria in G-6-PDH deficiency patients, as it causes oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

[Must Know]

[Primaquine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number: 885

questions.text: A 54 year old diabetic woman was seen in the emergency room 3 weeks ago with complaints of swelling, warmth, and pain in her foot. She was diagnosed with cellulitis and sent home on a 10-day course of an oral first-generation cephalosporin. She returns with severe diarrhea and Clostridium difficile is suspected. What is the initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Metronidazole is the preferred treatment for Clostridium difficile colitis, which probably resulted from the patient's use of a broad-spectrum antibiotic for her initial infection.
  • Vancomycin is considered in the treatment of Clostridium difficile colitis in refractory cases.

Metronidazole

  • It has broadspectrum cidal activity against anaerobic protozoa, including Giardia lamblia.
  • Many anaerobic and microaerophilic bacteria, such as fragilis, Fusobacterium,Clostridium perfringens, Cl. difficile, Helicobacter pylori, Campylobacter, peptococci, spirochetes and anaerobic Streptococci are sensitive.
  • Pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by difficile is generally associated with use of antibiotics.
  • Oral metronidazole is more effective, more convenient, less toxic, and therefore preferred over vancomycin which may be used in nonresponsive cases, or when the infection recurs.

Option A: The use of Clindamycin is often associated with Clostridium difficile colitis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin can be used for the treatment of diverticulitis, but not colitis.

Option D: Neomycin is used to sterilize the bowel, which is not the goal in this case.

Key Takeaway

  • Metronidazole is the preferred treatment for Clostridium difficile colitis, which probably resulted from the patient's use of a broad-spectrum antibiotic for her initial infection.

[Good to Know]

[Metronidazole]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number: 895-896

questions.text: A 66-year-old man recently diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis started a three-drug treatment with isoniazid, rifampin and ethambutol. The man, who had been suffering from atrial fibrillation for 4 years, was currently being treated with propranolol and warfarin. Which of the following changes in the patient's therapeutic regimen would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• Rifampin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of many drugs, including glucocorticoids, oral contraceptives, methadone, β-blockers, and warfarin.
  • Therefore, the dose of warfarin should be increased to maintain an appropriate anticoagulant effect.

Interactions

  • Rifampin is a microsomal enzyme inducer-increases several CYP450isoenzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP1A2 and CYP2C subfamily.
  • It thus enhances its own metabolism (area under the plasma concentration-time curve is reduced by ~35%) as well as that of many drugs like
  • Warfarin
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Corticosteroids
  • Sulfonylureas
  • Hiv protease inhibitors
  • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs)
  • Theophylline
  • Metoprolol
  • Fluconazole
  • Ketoconazole
  • Clarithromycin
  • Phenytoin

Contraceptive failures have occurred. It is advisable to switch over to an oral contraceptive containing higher dose (50 μg) of estrogen or use alternative method of contraception.

Key Takeaway

  • Rifampin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of warfarin, hence dose of warfarin should be increased to maintain an appropriate anticoagulant effect.

[May Know]

[Rifampicin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number: 818

questions.text: A 23 year old AIDS patient develops fever, neck pain, and photophobia. He is seen in the emergency room, where a lumbar puncture is performed. The cerebrospinal fluid reveals Cryptococcus neoformans on India ink stain. Which of the following agents is preferred for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
• Fluconazole is the best agent to treat cryptococcal meningitis and has good central nervous system (CNS) penetration.
  • Fluconazole
    • It is a water-soluble triazole having a wider range of activity.
    • Indications include cryptococcal meningitis, systemic and mucosal candidiasis in both normal and immunocompromised patients, coccidioidal meningitis and some tinea infections.

Option A & C: Tolnaftate and griseofulvin are topical agents used in dermatophyte infections.

Option D: Cycloserine is an alternative drug used for mycobacterial infections and is both nephrotoxic and causes seizures.

  • Key Takeaway
    • Fluconazole is the best agent to treat cryptococcal meningitis and has good central nervous system (CNS) penetration.

[Must Know]

[Fluconazole]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 844

questions.text: A 23 year old immunocompetent woman sees her family physician with painful "bumps" on her labia and vulva. On examination, there are vesicles in the described region. You suspect herpes simplex infection on clinical grounds and recommend which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Valacyclovir is related to acyclovir, both of which are used for the treatment of oral and genital herpes in immunocompetent individuals.
  • Valacyclovir
    • It is a valyl ester prodrug of acyclovir with improved oral bioavailability due to active transport by peptide transporters in the intestine.
    • During passage through intestine and liver, it is completely converted to acyclovir in the first passage by esterases.
    • Thus, >3 fold higher plasma levels of acyclovir are obtained improving clinical efficacy in certain conditions
    • It is the drug of choice in herpes zoster.
    • Valaciclovir is excreted in urine

Option A, C & D: All of these agents are not preferred choice of drugs for herpes zoster.

  • Key Takeaway
  • Valacyclovir is used for the treatment of oral and genital herpes in immunocompetent individuals.

[Good to Know]

[Valacyclovir]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 851

questions.text: A 37 year old woman presents with fever, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Blood tests reveal that she has an increase in her liver enzymes. In addition, hepatitis serology indicates that she has hepatitis B virus. Which of the following agents can be used in the management of this virus?
questions.solution:
• Lamivudine, a reverse transcriptase inhibitor of the HIV reverse transcriptase, also has activity against the reverse transcriptase of hepatitis B virus.
  • Lamivudine is also effective in chronic hepatitis B; in which lower doses are required than for HIV.
  • This may be due to longer intracellular t½ of lamivudine in HBV infected cells than in HIV infected cells.
  • HBV-DNA titre is markedly reduced and biochemical as well as histological indices of liver function improve.

Option B: Zidovudine does not display such cross-activity.

Option C: Ribavirin can be used in the treatment of hepatitis C, an RNA virus.

Option D: Acyclovir is only effective against the herpes family DNA polymerase.

  • Key Takeaway
  • Lamivudine, a reverse transcriptase inhibitor of the HIV reverse transcriptase, also has activity against the reverse transcriptase of hepatitis B virus.

[Good to Know]

[Lamivudine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:862

questions.text: A 35 year old patient developed viral pneumonia and was treated accordingly by his physician at intensive care unit. Few months later, patient presented with nasal congestion, sinusitis and swelling of face. There were black lesions on the nose bridge. On CT scan diagnosis of mucor-mycosis was made. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Amphotericin B can be applied topically for oral, vaginal and cutaneous candidiasis, fungal corneal ulcer and otomycosis.
  • It is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.
  • However, because of higher toxicity of AMB, the azole antifungals are now preferred in conditions where their efficacy approaches that of AMB.
  • In serious fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, initial induction therapy with AMB may be replaced by the alternative safer azole antifungal drug for continuation of therapy.
  • Febrile neutropenia: Empirical use of i.v. AMB is often made in neutropenic patients whose fever is not responding to i.v. bactericidal antibiotics.
  • Leishmaniasis: AMB is the most effective drug for resistant cases of kala azar and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis

Option A, B & D: All of these given agents are not the preferred drug for mucormycosis.

  • Key Takeaway
  • Amphotericin B is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.

[Must Know]

[Amphotericin B]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 840

questions.text: The mechanism of action by which pyrantel pamoate is effective for the treatment of Necator americanus (hookworm) disease is?
questions.solution:
• Pyrantel pamoate is an antihelminthic that acts primarily as a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker.
  • In certain worms, a spastic neuromuscular paralysis occurs, resulting in the expulsion of the worms from the intestinal tract of the host.
  • Pyrantel also exerts its effect against parasites via release of acetylcholine and inhibition of cholinesterase.
  • Pyrantel pamoate
    • It was introduced in 1969 for pin worm infestation in children; use soon extended to roundworm and hookworm as well.
    • Efficacy against Ascaris, Enterobius and Ancylostoma is high and comparable to that of mebendazole.
    • Pyrantel activates nicotinic cholinergic receptors in the worms resulting in persistent depolarization, giving rise to slowly developing contracture and spastic paralysis. Worms are then expelled.
    • Use and administration
    • For Ascaris, Ancylostoma and Enterobius: a single dose of 11 mg/kg is recommended. A 3 day course for Necator and for Strongyloides is needed.
  • Key Takeaway
    • Pyrantel activates nicotinic cholinergic receptors in the worms resulting in persistent depolarization, giving rise to slowly developing contracture and spastic paralysis. Worms are then expelled.

[May Know]

[Pyrantel pamoate]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 909
